prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
** Technical considerations **
We propose to perform a deep spectral line and continuum survey in a 1 arcmin^2 region in the Hubble UDF. The unique depth and frequency coverage of this program will bring forth unexplored regimes which will lead to transformational science with ALMA in full array in later cycles.
- Observational Strategy:
We aim to obtain a deep 7-point mosaic in the UDF. We will sample a region of roughly 1 arcmin^2 using 20" offset between pointings (~2/3 of the primary beam), and thus obtain nearly homogeneous coverage. We choose a small mosaic to overcome cosmic variance in small scales and to probe the relevant environment at $z\sim2$: a smaller region (i.e.~a single band-6 pointing) would not allow us to properly cover the full range of the CO and FIR luminosity functions below their knee. In addition, the extent of this 7-pointing mosaic nicely complements the coverage of the ALMA band-3 primary beam in our companion proposal.We will use the ALMA C34-1 or C34-2 array configurations (both are acceptable) to obtain an angular resolution of roughly 1.0"-1.5". This resolution is needed to dissentangle individual sources without out-resolving the emission.
- Frequency:
We will scan almost the full band-6 using 8 different frequency setups, with a full coverage range of 212-272 GHz (60 GHz bandwidth). We chose this band to cover the CO emission at 0<z<4, [CII] emission at 6<z<8, and at the same time get a continuum map at unprecedented depth. Furthermore, this band provides a larger fractional bandwidth, larger field of view and better atmospheric transparency with respect to band-7. These compensate the fact that band-7 traces a higher part of the dust SED from distant galaxies.
- Correlator setup and bandwidth:
We aim to cover the larger possible bandwidth while keeping enough velocity resolution to be able to resolve relatively narrow lines from distant galaxies (50 km/s line-width in some cases; see Carilli et al. 2013). We will use the correlator in FDM mode, with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz per baseband, making a total of 7.5 GHz per tuning, and using a spectral channel averaging factor of 16. This leads to approximately 10 km/s channel width. Including all 8 frequency tunings (one per science goal), we will be covering a total bandwidth of 60 GHz. We follow the approach suggested by the OT 'scan-mode' (not available for mosaics) for setting up the frequency tunings, and place each baseband next to each other contiguously. In this way, we are able to cover a larger frequency range more efficiently.
- Sensitivity:
We aim to reach a 1-sigma line sensitivity of 0.23 mJy per 300 km/s channel. For CO, this translates into a CO luminosity of ~1.6x10^9 K km/s pc^2 for a galaxy at z=1.5, assuming a line width of 300 km/s. Depending on the actual CO excitation, this implies CO(1-0) luminosities of (0.3-1.5)x10^10 K km/s pc^2 or H_2 masses down to 2.5x10^9 Msun (5-sigma), depending on the conversion factor (Dame 2001; Downes & Solomon 1998).
For [CII] line emission at z=6-8, we expect that, assuming a typical L_[CII]/L_FIR ratio of 3.5e-3 (e.g. Stacey et al. 2010) and line-width of 300 km/s, a galaxy with SFR>10 M_sun/yr would be detected with a significance of >5-sigma (S_[CII]>1 mJy). Finally, for the full covered bandwidth of 60 GHz, this line sensitivity leads to an rms level of 13-14 micro-Jy in the continuum. This yields that we will be able to detect galaxies with L_FIR>10^11 L_sun out to z=8.
- Imaging and calibration:
We do not have special imaging requirements. We expect most of the sources to be point-like, and thus do not require exquisite uv coverage.Similarly, we do not have special calibration requirements. We will use the observatory provided calibration.
- Data rates:
We are asking for the most simple possible setup and correlator output that will allow us to accomplish our scientific goals. We will not exceed the maximum allowed data rates.

** Technical considerations **
We propose to perform a deep spectral line and continuum survey in a 1 arcmin^2 region in the Hubble UDF. The unique depth and frequency coverage of this program will bring forth unexplored regimes which will lead to transformational science with ALMA in full array in later cycles.
- Observational Strategy:
We aim to obtain a deep 7-point mosaic in the UDF. We will sample a region of roughly 1 arcmin^2 using 20" offset between pointings (~2/3 of the primary beam), and thus obtain nearly homogeneous coverage. We choose a small mosaic to overcome cosmic variance in small scales and to probe the relevant environment at $z\sim2$: a smaller region (i.e.~a single band-6 pointing) would not allow us to properly cover the full range of the CO and FIR luminosity functions below their knee. In addition, the extent of this 7-pointing mosaic nicely complements the coverage of the ALMA band-3 primary beam in our companion proposal.We will use the ALMA C34-1 or C34-2 array configurations (both are acceptable) to obtain an angular resolution of roughly 1.0"-1.5". This resolution is needed to dissentangle individual sources without out-resolving the emission.
- Frequency:
We will scan almost the full band-6 using 8 different frequency setups, with a full coverage range of 212-272 GHz (60 GHz bandwidth). We chose this band to cover the CO emission at 0<z<4, [CII] emission at 6<z<8, and at the same time get a continuum map at unprecedented depth. Furthermore, this band provides a larger fractional bandwidth, larger field of view and better atmospheric transparency with respect to band-7. These compensate the fact that band-7 traces a higher part of the dust SED from distant galaxies.
- Correlator setup and bandwidth:
We aim to cover the larger possible bandwidth while keeping enough velocity resolution to be able to resolve relatively narrow lines from distant galaxies (50 km/s line-width in some cases; see Carilli et al. 2013). We will use the correlator in FDM mode, with a bandwidth of 1.875 GHz per baseband, making a total of 7.5 GHz per tuning, and using a spectral channel averaging factor of 16. This leads to approximately 10 km/s channel width. Including all 8 frequency tunings (one per science goal), we will be covering a total bandwidth of 60 GHz. We follow the approach suggested by the OT 'scan-mode' (not available for mosaics) for setting up the frequency tunings, and place each baseband next to each other contiguously. In this way, we are able to cover a larger frequency range more efficiently.
- Sensitivity:

For CO, this translates into a CO luminosity of ~1.6x10^9 K km/s pc^2 for a galaxy at z=1.5, assuming a line width of 300 km/s. Depending on the actual CO excitation, this implies CO(1-0) luminosities of (0.3-1.5)x10^10 K km/s pc^2 or H_2 masses down to 2.5x10^9 Msun (5-sigma), depending on the conversion factor (Dame 2001; Downes & Solomon 1998).
For [CII] line emission at z=6-8, we expect that, assuming a typical L_[CII]/L_FIR ratio of 3.5e-3 (e.g. Stacey et al. 2010) and line-width of 300 km/s, a galaxy with SFR>10 M_sun/yr would be detected with a significance of >5-sigma (S_[CII]>1 mJy). Finally, for the full covered bandwidth of 60 GHz, this line sensitivity leads to an rms level of 13-14 micro-Jy in the continuum. This yields that we will be able to detect galaxies with L_FIR>10^11 L_sun out to z=8.
- Imaging and calibration:
We do not have special imaging requirements. We expect most of the sources to be point-like, and thus do not require exquisite uv coverage.Similarly, we do not have special calibration requirements. We will use the observatory provided calibration.
- Data rates:
We are asking for the most simple possible setup and correlator output that will allow us to accomplish our scientific goals. We will not exceed the maximum allowed data rates.

- Data rates:
We are asking for the most simple possible setup and correlator output that will allow us to accomplish our scientific goals. We will not exceed the maximum allowed data rates.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to obtain an unbiased, deep CO/[CII] spectral scan and (parallel) ultra-deep continuum imaging toward a region in the Hubble Ultra Deep Field (UDF) using ALMA in band-6. We aim to encompass a region of 1 arcmin^2 in a 7-point mosaic, covering the entire band-6 through frequency scans, thus comprising the main epoch of galaxy assembly at 0<z<4 for CO line emission and 15 newly discovered Lyman break galaxies at 6<z<8 for [CII]. We expect to detect at least 25 CO emitters and 30 continuum sources down to an H2 mass limit of 2.5x10^9 Msun and FIR luminosities of 1x10^11 Lsun (5-sigma). These observations will allow us to measure the CO luminosity function, and thus H2 mass function, well below its knee, providing unprecedented constraints on the evolution of the cosmic density of molecular gas. Most importantly, this unique study will open new unexplored regimes by detection of serendipitous CO line emitters at 0<z<4, and may represent the only means to confirm redshifts for several galaxies at z=6-8, which have proven extremely difficult to obtain through optical/NIR spectroscopy.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: In a companion proposal (Walter et al.), we seek to obtain a deep spectroscopic survey of the same region with ALMA in band-3 and thus covering a different redshift range z=2-8 (for CO). Both projects combined will enable a comprehensive study for molecular gas and dust emission from galaxies over the full epoch of galaxy formation from z=0.2-8.0. Covering both bands will allow us to confirm the redshift of galaxies, even though the band-6 coverage itself covers 2 lines for 60% of the redshift range 0<z<3, and also to obtain CO excitation measurements based on >2 lines.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
